title: When will the 7-day moving average of daily cases of COVID-19 in the US reported to the CDC next be 50,000 or lower?
preds: 49,905 on 3 Mar as of today, so resolution expected by 8th, or later this week at the latest.
Adding in the weekend, and we are already there.

Recent estimate of 3rd - 8th March may be just too early, due to a high case count on 28th Feb (108k). 
But current 7-day average is <56k and the most recent three days ~52.5k, so the next 4-6 days are still looking very possible. 
The concern is whether increasing levels of BA.2, behavioural factors or some other unknown slows the decline to plateau just above 50k, but so far no signal.
most recent 7 day avg 75k - with a 37% decrease from last update...

Carefully monitoring the removal of mask mandates throughout the country negatively affecting rate of decrease, but with 3+ weeks left in March the data trend puts a prior to 31 March target within reach.
Moving average is 56k and still dropping... surely we will go down another 10% in the next 3 weeks

Re-adjusting forecast based on precipitous rate of decline in cases. I do think the 7-day rate will hang in the mid 50 to 60 % range for some time, based on the last surge. The only difference is that I see a bevy of normalization measures across the states in terms of dropping mask mandates, proof of vaccination, etc. and a higher proliferation of at-home testing options (read: not reported to CDC). This suggests the numbers may fall more dramatically versus hanging as it did in Jan 21.  I am more confident though that we will not go below the 50K in the next 31 days. (current 7-day rate is ~62K)

The rate of decline has slowed.  The end of March is still possible, even likely.  But if the rate flattens and heads higher then it's anybody's guess.  The trend is your friend, until it isn't.  The next couple of data points will be crucial.

With a higher daily count yesterday the next few days would need to all average <50k, which is extremely unlikely, so it may be that numbers are starting to flatten off before reaching the target this week

current 7 day avg is 68k - and there has been a pretty drastic drop over last couple of weeks - assumption of no new strain and continued decrease - we should see below 50k in the next couple of weeks (I estimate mid-March)

I'm going a little lower on bin 2 right now because I think we're starting to see the effects of BA.2 together with the limits of immunity, and I'm concerned that it's possible that cases may not reach 50k by the end of March. The example of South Africa comes to mind. Yesterday's data have a "Sunday effect," but if we don't see at least a bit of a drop in today's data, then I'll really start to wonder. We have seen perfect exponential decline from Feb 1 to around Feb 25 or 26. The curve may now be starting to deviate from that, as the BA.2 curve starts to add noticeable numbers of cases on top of the Omicron curve. If I do an exponential fit to only the past week's data, the projection says March 7 (R^2 = 0.894). With the past 17 days of data, the projection is March 2 (R^2 = 0.985). With all of Feb so far, the projection is now March 2 (R^2 = 0.997).
It currently still looks likely between 3rd and 8th, as from forecast yesterday

As of yesterday, 7-day avg. was ~65k/day.
 Credible date range for first sub-50k report (if current trends continue approximately) is between [March 2, March 12]. Best estimate is March 6. 
~1% chance assessed that, e.g., new variant effects, changes in reporting behaviors, or new wave of reinfections, etc. would delay further decreases in 7-day avg. sufficiently to create bin #3+ outcomes.
There is a slim chance cases will plateau just above 50k but currently it looks likely around  3rd - 8th March.
The projection still says March 1 (+/- 1 day), but the 7-day average of cases just went up very slightly, for the first time in a long time.

I think the US could see a continuing fall for two/three weeks, which would be enough to get below 50k even if cases plateau and rise after that. As time progresses and the incentive to test recedes, only more severe symptomatic cases may be detected, reducing reported case rates further. As a comparison, cases are still declining in the UK, even with precautionary measures becoming lax, and with BA.2 gaining ground at a higher level than the US (approx 11% as of last week).

With data updated to Feb 1-24, a projection of exponential decline still predicts March 1 (+/- 1 day because the data are noisy). ~5 more days of data. There may be the slightest suggestion of a slowdown in the decrease, so it may actually happen around March 2.
Cases are dropping quickly. Reserving some possibility for later dates for potential surges.
With data updated to Feb 1-23, a projection of exponential decline still predicts March 1 (+/- 1 day because the data are noisy). ~6 more days of data.

With data updated to Feb 1-22, a projection of exponential decline still predicts March 1 (+/- 1 day because the data are noisy). ~7 more days of data. The only reason I'm not at 100% is BA.2. "BA.2 has now been found from coast to coast and accounts for an estimated 3.9% all new infections nationally, according to the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. It appears to be doubling fast. "If it doubles again to 8%, that means we're into the exponential growth phase and we may be staring at another wave of COVID-19 coming in the U.S.," says Samuel Scarpino, the manager director of pathogen surveillance at the Rockefeller Foundation."
https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2022/02/21/1081810074/omicron-ba2-variant-spread The 3.9% they're referring to above is the (incomplete) CDC "Nowcast" data for the week ending 2/19/22 -- meaning that a higher proportion of infections happening right now are actually caused by BA.2, more likely close to 6% or so. As BA.2 spreads, it is likely to slow down the decline in cases.
https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#variant-proportions

The trend is showing an increasingly sharper decline, but it's still hard to predict given how long it's been since we were at 50,000. Vaccines being available for younger children should put downward pressure on the trend, while pushback on masking might be an upward pressure. I'm adjusting toward an earlier date, but want to watch it as we get closer to each deadlne.
The rate of decline shows no sign of slowing, but that could still change.  I'm betting for a continuation of the trend for at least another week.

The daily average is falling dramatically and based on @ricknsusan1314 the next CDC report will likely be significant. That being said there is always the possibility of a new variant coming out any day or a plateau before a final drop. Will check again in a few days.

Data moved, so did I...looks like 1st or 2nd week of March if this rate  holds: https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/covid-data/covidview/index.html#:~:text=As%20of%20February%2016%2C%202022,as%20of%20February%2016%2C%202022

IAW the CDC: "As of February 16, 2022, the current 7-day moving average of daily new cases (121,665) decreased 43.0% compared with the previous 7-day moving average (213,625). A total of 78,060,327 COVID-19 cases have been reported in the United States as of February 16, 2022."  Given this current trajectory, I adjusted my forecast to a more aggressive stance that it will drop below 50K in March, but left a little wiggle room for a latent April drop since the CDC may or may not capture the data in enough time to publish it.  https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/covid-data/covidview/index.html#:~:text=As%20of%20February%2016%2C%202022,as%20of%20February%2016%2C%202022

Just realised that reporting for yesterday may be short due to the 3rd Monday in February Federal Holiday relating to Washington's birthday?
I'll leave the forecast for now and see what happens later in the week
7-day avg. at 85.5k now. Still apparently dropping ~50k/every ~6-7 days. Unless BA.2 starts really making an impact in the next week or so this is over.
Adjusting every day for now while it's falling...until it goes below or stops and moves to bin 3.

Halving time roughly 7 days at the moment. If it goes a little slower it should still make it below 50K next month. There is a chance that it levels out above 50k but I'm thinking there are two factors driving prevelance down:
- Actual reduction in transmission and infection
- Less motivation to get tested for mild symptoms or asymptomatic cases
With data updated to Feb 1-21, a projection of exponential decline still predicts March 1. 8 more days.

Adjusting forecast to be *slightly* more favorable towards a 50K average by the end of March. Still mostly sticking with data from CDC. The biggest indicators to watch will be new variants and where the daily volume will trend despite the omicron smash seemingly dissipating.

I don’t think BA.2 will affect cases for a few weeks yet, and a reduction in testing could help push down the number of cases being reported. They may plateau beforehand but <50k looks more realistic than it did two weeks ago.

Continued decline in REPORTED new infections. Now projecting a credible date range (Bootstrap resampling before fitting decline curves) between [Feb 27 March 17]. Best estimate is March 5. 
~20% chance assessed that the US COVID evolution won’t be well-modeled by this analytic approach and its implicit assumptions (e.g., no new variant effects, change in reporting behaviors, new wave of reinfections, etc.), leading to bin #3+ outcomes.
With data updated to Feb 1-19, a projection of exponential decline still predicts March 1.
Already dipped below the pre-omicron rate. I'm surprised by the continued velocity of decline. I suspect a decline in asymptomatic/surveillance testing is accelerating the trend.

Revising a little later because BA.2. But BA.2 has been here and has been growing slowly as a percentage of cases. Which will win over the next couple weeks, Omicron cases falling or BA.2 cases rising?

Since the end of January the rate of decrease in new cases has averaged about 7.5% per day.  There is no guarantee the rate of decline will continue, but I'm betting heavily that it will.  If it does we'll be under 50k in less than two weeks, as recently predicted by @belikewater.  This one could be over soon.

I just projected out the data from Feb 1 with an exponential fit, and the fit predicts we'll see cases <50k/day on March 1 (with some uncertainty, obviously), R^2 = 0.996. Now, BA.2 has yet to hit the US in earnest, and everything is subject to change and new variants, but it's quite possible that we will see <50k cases/day before March 31. @paulm
Radically changed my forecast-- the fall from 800K has been welcome.

I haven't looked at this question in a while. Again I need to try to disprove my current thought. Changed in favor of an earlier 7 day average. Basing that on dramatic drop changing from a high of 880,774 total/803,640 7 day daily average, 15 Jan 22 to 103,866 total/119,291 7day daily average, 17 Feb 22.

I'm reducing my confidence it "won't" happen, and therefore that it will happen sooner. Primarily because I think the "reporting/recording" accuracy of covid cases will fade as covid becomes endemic....just part of the day to day... as it nearly is now...

Re-adjusting my forecast based on the 7-day moving average reaching 112,653 cases by February 18th - a full 3 months prior to my earlier forecast (161,124 by May 5th). My base rating was clearly incorrect in terms of how quickly the case rate decline would be....but hey - thats Omicron for you. I am still not convinced we will fall below 50K prior to March 31st in a transition period between endemic and pandemic style restrictions. I see the case rate declining far more rapidly when restrictions are lifted and a national reorientation on COVID as an endemic versus a pandemic.

Over the past 3 weeks cases are falling by almost half from Monday to Friday of a week. The week ending 18 Feb will end with a daily case of approximately 100K.  
With 5 weeks remaining using similar rates of reduction the 7-day average should fall to < 50K in approximately 3-4 weeks. Roughly March 15, 2022.
Reducing mask mandates, loosening restrictions, and a new variant might create some rise in spread of infection, it will likely be mitigated by a number of factors.
At home testing is more frequent with free tests, but also doesn't end up being reported for CDC tracking.
Reduced severity of current dominant variant coupled with reduced restrictions will result in fewer people seeking testing.
As weather begins to improve out of winter months more activities will occur outdoors.
At the current rate of decline, we should be under 100k next week and under 50k two weeks later.

Cases dropping quickly now. Raw number of tests also dropping, and also test positivity. It's important that this is reported cases, so a dropping number of tests will reduce the value further. I think the chance of this resolving in bin 2 is increasing. In the last 10 days reported cases have halved. If they half again by the end of Feb bin 2 will be in touching distance. The world is fast approaching the point where we stop mass testing and move to surveillance. It seems that might happen in the UK as soon as next week. I think that the appetite to get tested will probably recede very quickly at this point. The only way I see it not happening before May is some new variant appearing.

7-day avg. now dropping through 150k/day level, taking 4-5 days to drop by ~50k/day. Even assuming a progressive doubling of the time to drop each additional 50k/day, we’d get:
- ~100k/day around Feb. 24
- ~ 50k/day around Mar. 16 with plenty room to spare in bin #2. Other less drastic models can predict 50k/day well within this month! I’m not super convinced by these reference calculations but I see a very credible trend in the data pointing at bin #2, with only a 100k/day drop left to play for. Perhaps more variants will change the trajectory, into later bins, but there’s not a lot of observable evidence for that scenario in the data.
Adjusting based on rapid case rate decline over past few weeks.

South Africa has been plateaued for a month, the UK is still at 50% of peak infections, and Canada is nearly 25% of peak but rate of decrease has been slower than the initial drop. Obviously different countries are different, and US cases have been dropping rapidly (though the rate of decrease has clearly slowed).

So on my last forecast I called the peak about 5 days early (actually occurred ~ Jan 15th), and about 90K cases high on the 7-day moving average (actual was 805,624). I still contend the rate of decrease will be similar to the Jan 2021 surge - meaning an 80% decrement every ~110 days. I stand by: 805,624 on Jan 15, 2022
161,124 on May 5, 2022
32,224 on August 22, 2022 I am 90% certain the rate will be below 50K prior to 1 August so lowering that prediction. With the wider proliferation of at-home testing I think that will drive down CDC or Health Department reported tests, which could drive the rate down sooner - so I am increasing probability the 7-day average hits >50K prior to 31 July.

from the last numbers of 7Feb, we have seen a pretty substantial decrease daily since the last peak - if the trend continues - then dropping below 50k could happen before end of February - but this does not factor in another strain

I'm not sure what to think. If BA.2 were to become dominant (which it will) and its progeny to continue to circulate, we could easily expect >60% of the population to be infected each year - and to see many reinfections as well. If 90% of those infections were to occur in winter (and I think that would be an overestimate), then we'd expect to see 0.1 * 0.6 * 330M / 275 days * 1000 = 72k/day average for the rest of the year, without even considering reinfections. Of course, no variant has lasted that long, but the variants that have replaced the ones before have been more contagious, not less. Also, at that level of infections, we can expect to detect 1/3 to 1/4 of all infections, so we'd record ~72k/3.5 = 21k/day. So I see a huge amount of uncertainty here. How big of a bump will BA.2 cause, if any? How low will cases fall with BA.2 in the spring? Will another variant come along before Aug 1?
I think we'll know a lot soon. But, we're already starting to see a slight slowdown in the decline.

Daily average is down 42% according to CNN, and this MayoClinic website, so I am focusing my forecast by eliminating "Not before 1 August".  There is debate that the USG purchase and distribution of tests and masks will have an impact, but I cannot find anything definitely studied to confirm it at this time. https://www.mayoclinic.org/coronavirus-covid-19/map?mc_id=google&campaign=12619887048&geo=9008163&kw=covid%20cases%20in%20us&ad=509662149079&network=g&sitetarget=&adgroup=120372571656&extension=&target=kwd-923960141682&matchtype=p&device=c&account=7470347919&placementsite=enterprise&gclid=EAIaIQobChMI8d_DhMfw9QIVSXFvBB19GQ2tEAAYAiAAEgJWqfD_BwE
I'm not sure what BA.2 is going to do. It's ~30-34% more contagious than its parent Omicron, and immunity wanes quickly after milder infections. How low will infections go?
Cases trending downward but not likely fast enough to drop below 50K before the end of March.

If we extrapolate the current trend we'll see <50k/day before the end of February.  The crowd apparently is skeptical of this outcome, with only a 13% chance.  I am more optimistic, but don't want to go all-in against the crowd.  At some point before spring arrives the numbers could flatten before again turning downward.  Or they could even resume their climb.  Over the past two years COVID has been full of surprises.

Assuming that no significant new COVID variants emerge soon (recall that going from discovery of Omicron to seeing high rates in US took only a little over a month!), I think that we’re looking at a bin-boundary (#2-3) outcome. Everything depends on how much shallower the curve will get (currently very steeply declining) as we approach 50k/day 7-day averages. I’m not sure that we have a clear picture of what the “endemic baseline” will eventually reveal itself to be (we very probably will not see sustained 0/day, sadly, thanks to our “vaxx-sceptical” fellow citizens, but could it actually be above 50k/day?!) and the magnitude of downward impact that home-testing has on national statistics is also hard to know. I think those might be the two key factors to watch for. For now, though, I’ll start slightly preferring bin #2, recalling forecasting rule #1 for Omicron: “everything happens much faster than you’d think possible based on previous experience.”

I believe that the only reason why cases didn't fall to <50k/day last spring was because Alpha arrived. This time, cases are falling far more rapidly, with no new variant on the horizon. BA.2 is coming up in prevalence, of course, but I don't think it will cause much of a bump in cases, if any, although I think it could slow the decline in cases. But with cases falling extremely quickly, I think <50k/day is likely within the next few weeks.
Case rate is falling fast coupled with future testing being less reported might drive numbers lower much lower.

It's starting to look like BA.2 won't cause a substantial bump, based on South Africa data. I expect that the US should see <100k cases/day within 2-3 weeks or so, or perhaps a little later, depending on what BA.2 does. The question in my mind is how low cases will go, as immunity to Omicron seems to be of such short duration.

stats through the end of January have been seeing a pretty continuous drop (approx 18700 a day) - if current decrease continues - then end of Febuary is a potential for falling below 50000 7 day moving average for cases - this assumes no new varients emerging
Lowering Bin 2 as BA.2 becomes a bigger issue. I'll be watching South Africa closely to see if BA.2 is just a temporary problem or if it causes another large wave.

I have made an update but have not changed my numbers drastically because in looking through information there still seems to be lack of data. Omicron is known to have an aggressive transmission rate (approximately 7.0 or higher) so until we see a sharper trend, such as a sharp decline will be difficult to forecast.

Pre-Omicron 7 day averages were not nearing 50,000.  Extremely unlikely to occur in the next 30 days given the rate relationship/pattern I observe in previous declines.  Still unsure how to best probability of next mutation's impact as well to include when/timeline, thus forecast remains strong to persist above 50,000 for the majority of 2022 for now.
Now at 497,294 and dropping fast but omicron is still yet to reach many areas.

Omicron has presented with consistently narrow peaked waves.  The current numbers do not reflect the true size of the wave which may make forecasting more difficult. Also theirs that small possibility of a new variant that gets around vaccines and previously infected.

Adjusting forecast (less weight on earlier bins) to reflect documented spread of BA.2 + increased sentiment expressed by pundits/politicians that “We have to learn how to live with this” BEFORE the current peak has subsided back to something approaching a reasonable baseline.  (‘endemic’ scenarios with baselines of 100k’s of new cases per day nationally—sustained through re-infection and/or new variants combined with inadequate preventative measures taken—are obviously rather more disruptive and painful compared to ‘endemic’ scenarios with 1000’s to 10k’s per day baselines created through sustained application of precautions…
not wearing masks / taking all other reasonable precautions possible at this time or failing to maintain vaccination status just “because the virus is now endemic” is just ignorant, selfish, and super-counter-productive even from a purely self-interested perspective. Much of the US almost seems hell-bent on maximizing the baseline rates between future peaks “because we’re sick of talking about COVID”. The trajectory of COVID so far and in the future is not controlled by luck—it reflects the consequences of our collective choices. This makes it harder to be optimistic about what comes next.)

Well, I was thinking bin 2 would happen, but it looks like we just can't catch a break. BA.2 is starting to come up in South Africa now, and it looks like it's about to either keep cases from falling or cause another wave. So, for now, I'm revising later until we can see what this thing is capable of.
https://twitter.com/TWenseleers/status/1487919837670219781

SA and UK new cases have dropped dramatically, but both have plateaued at rates above their pre-Omicron levels. I just don't see US dropping below pre-Omicron anytime soon, so maintaining my forecast but with a slight tilt towards the crowd, given that new cases in the US are still falling rapidly.

It appears this outcome will be driven not by actual cases, but solely by cases reported via hospitalizations or targeted sentinel surveillance in select areas - schools, large workplaces (>100 etc).
The recent free at home testing has no reporting chain for positive results. The intent being personal knowledge and responsibility should guide actions. By in large individuals will not take the extra steps to report their condition unless some workplace or care giving policy requires and that organization may or may not be required or take the time to report to CDC. In some cases there is no requirement to up report. Separate from that, while omicron peak is definitely past, it seems reinfections are not uncommon. Potentially raising the floor of endemic infections to greater than 50,000. Especially as masking and event capacity limits retract and vaccinations remain plateaued.  Adjusting forecast for a longer tail after the omicron spike. Much more testing (not all reported), combined with fewer limits on spreading should keep reported numbers higher for longer.

Once again updating numbers based on the current decline and the potential that the fall could be has violent as the rise. Although, the data also indicates that omicron peaks are just now cascading in other parts of the US and this could impact an exponential decay. source -> https://www.businessinsider.com/omicron-cases-could-peak-fall-quickly-in-us-models-2022-1

Whether a new variant emerges, or BA.2 becomes prevalent, will become more significant as the Omicron wave subsides. I'm expecting that relatively low third dose vaccinations, combined with reinfection rates, will cause the curve to decline more slowly on the tail pushing the outcome beyond March. But from there I think testing will also reduce as people lose motivation to test unless symptoms are severe (which will happen less often). A base level may then tick over till one of the above affects the status quo. The chances of a new variant are high, but a new more transmissible or contagious variant taking hold is less certain.
So far April and May are still looking the likeliest to me.

The omicron wave seems to be dropping quickly, and the previous curves, and this one, looks like bell curves.  The tail of this curve looks like it will be low by late March.  While there will likely be more variants, people maybe start taking fewer tests or do so in the privacy of their homes and not report their positive tests.

updated - based on numbers from CDC website for Jan 18-21 - saw a peak of around 756k cases daily and there has been a fairly sharp avg drop daily over the last couple of days (approx 13k daily) - shifting projection from mid june to march/april timeframe

Adjusting down my initial heavy prediction of 'not before August 1' to account for the downward trend in cases that just started at the end of January. Assuming that the curve back down is a mirror image of the curve up, that would have us back to 50,000 right around the end of July.
BA.2 hasn't hit the US yet, but it will soon. How big of a surge will it cause?
Lowering bin 2 because of BA.2, which seems to be able to reinfect at least some people who have already had Omicron. I'm watching to see how this situation develops.
Omicron cases starting to peak in some areas of the US; unknown if other variants will emerge.

I really think bin 2 is underrated. 
Trevor Bedford: "Case counts for the US appear to have peaked at a 7-day average of 806k on Jan 14. Omicron grew from approximately 35k daily cases on Dec 14 to ~800k daily cases in ~4 weeks."
https://twitter.com/trvrb/status/1483996702608551936
If the decline were as fast as the rise in cases, we'd end up <50k/day by early February. The decline will be a bit slower, but we could conceivably even end up at <50k/day before the end of February. Last year, what prevented us from reaching <50k/day in by the end of March was Alpha; we don't see any such new variant on the horizon yet. We don't yet know how long immunity to Omicron will last, but I don't see why it should last any shorter amount of time compared to immunity to any other variant. I think the only reason we wouldn't see <50k/day in bin 2 would be if a new variant emerged. That could still very well happen, so I leave open that possibility.

Looking like the peak 7-day average will not hit my previous estimate (900k) so adjusting the forecast to something closer to 800k fitted to the previous exponential decay estimate. On the one hand, it appears we'll make it through omicron. On the other hand, the potential for variants and delayed omicron spreads throughout the country may keep the 7-day average steadily higher for longer.

Revision from previous forecast: Base rate: Using the January 2021 surge; similar to current surge in 1) vaccines available - although not as prevalent as they are today, and 2) winter season marked by more indoor contact by individuals practicing relaxed social distancing following the rollout of vaccinations (similar to our current state of being).  New cases peaked on January 8th 2021 at 294,000 cases (6.7% infection rate). On January 11, 2021 the 7-day moving average peaked at 250,541 daily cases (a 3 day lag between the peak cases and peak 7-day average). It was May 1, 2021 before the 7-day moving average dropped below 50K daily cases. I don't do math, so I am going to say generally that 7-day moving average cases decreased by 80% over 110 days.  This article from January 6, 2022 suggests that the US Omicron variant peak could be in the next few weeks, followed by a rapid decline in cases as evidenced by current observations in South Africa and the UK. This sentiment is being reported widely, so I take it at face value that the statement is *generally* accurate given the really smart doctors and scientists weighing in. For planning purposes I will assume the US will peak in new daily COVID cases on or about January 20, 2022, based on the swift reaction across parts of the US to contain the infection rate. https://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2022/01/omicron-could-peak-in-u-s-fairly-soon-maybe/  I am also assuming that the decline in cases will follow the trend of the previous January 2021 surge in terms of rate. I attribute rate (increase or decline) as a factor of the size, demographics, density, and ideological / political leanings of our country, which have not changed much since last January. Specifically, I dont think there will be a sharper decline in the 7-day average.  As of January 7, 2022 new cases were reported at 831,304 with a 7-day moving average of 668,497 (18.16% infection rate). 
**Update** As of January 14, 2022 new cases were reported at 874,087 with a 7-day moving average of 798,335 (16.83% infection rate).  **Update**: On closer inspection of CDC data it appears that the 7-day moving average growth rate has been: Dec 24-31 92.95%, Jan 1-7 70.68%, Jan 8 - 14 18.73%. Data suggests the rate of increase is dropping precipitously. I am 90% sure the next growth rate will be more than 5% but less than 19% so I intend to say the growth through Jan 20th will be 12%.  Based on this number I estimate the 7-day moving average to be in the neighborhood of 894,135 on January 20, 2022.  So - how many days to go from 7-day average of 894,135, down to 49.9K? Using my terribly rudimentary rate, I project the 7-day moving average to be: 894,135 on Jan 20, 2022
178,826 on May 9, 2022
35,765 on August 26, 2022

Using past case data on Delta from CDC as a base as well as initial Omicron transmission rates, Omicron cases could continue for an extended time on the assumption it’s simply less severe, lockdowns are unreasonable (given low morbidity rate), and vaccines continue to protect against severe effects Vice transmission.

Has anyone done any research into what level of cases and endemic Covid would run at if current testing levels continue?  Would that be below 50k?  Might need to look into it.  With high levels of testing come higher levels of cases reported,  and if there is US financial support for testing, this will maintain higher numbers for longer. It took 3 weeks for the current peak of 700k to be reached, given higher rates of infections and expose, this could drop off quite fast as the cases are all bunched together, so keeping a sensible probability for reaching this before the end of March.

Omicron cases have seemingly peaked in the US as a whole. It has taken just under a month for cases to rise from ~130 to the peak, so it should take just a bit more for cases to fall again to that level. Omicron cases are superimposed on Delta cases, and we still need to understand more what's going on with Delta. But I suspect that Omicron cases, by themselves, will be below 50k/day by the end of Feb. I think the only reason why US cases didn't fall below 50k last March was because Alpha came up. We don't yet see a new, important variant on the horizon, but on the other hand, it would be hard to detect a signal during the Omicron wave. If no new variant emerges, I do think we'll see <50k/day in March. Increasing the weight a little more on bin 2. I don't anticipate changing this forecast for a while, as it'll be important to see how quickly cases decline, what Delta is doing, and whether a new variant emerges.
Omicron has just about peaked, and no new, more contagious variant is yet on the horizon. Increasing the weight on bin 2.

UK and SA initial rates of change (post-peak) of new infection rates are encouraging, and point to bin #2 if directly extrapolated to the US and assumed to continue until very low levels of new infection are achieved. However I think the post-peak rate of change in the US will most likely slow down before we get to anywhere near 50k/day (compartmentalization).

Naive take, but
- Daily cases would not fall so fast to go below 0.5 mil before this month is over… that’s 2 weeks?
- Feb and March assumes we’re peaking around time I forecast, and with a slow decrease in case numbers I don’t know whether the later options should be “slow decay” or “undulating up and down but not quite falling past 0.5m”
If cases do keep bobbing up and down above 0.5 million, then not after Aug 10 should actually be higher but I haven’t a clue. Not sure if all the outcomes are too even - at first I was nearly going with 40% at the Feb March period because it may be peaking, but shucks??

The 7 day moving average should decline rapidly from its current peak as larger percentages of the population get the infection and get vaccinated. Nevertheless only 74% of the US population has been fully vaccinated as of January 11, 2022. The virus and possible future variants will continue to spread until a larger percentage are fully vaccinated. https://ourworldindata.org/covid-vaccinations

I find it interesting that people are comparing the "Omicron Wave" to other waves when there is no logical reason to compare them.   Omicron might as well be entirely different pandemic entirely as it:
1) Bypasses Vaccine
2) Has a significantly higher transmissibility rate
3) Has a much lower hospitalization and mortality rate If all of these are different, why would/should we assume that the wave will be the same?  The only reason I don't have a much higher probability that we don't get below 50k before August is that the virus will burn itself out in many of my underlying scenarios.  (i.e. we reach herd immunity).  Do not take the probability in my buckets as anything except a small probability that it really is just a wave, and a very high probability that it burns out. As far as I can tell, the only positive news and only country reporting something promising is South Africa, which somehow managed to keep cases no higher than the prior "wave."  Going to believe something is amiss with their data and may just be a lack of testing.

It stands to reason that the new variant will be better controlled in the mid-term based on necessity as well as the progression of medical tests/vaccines.  This is faster than the same timeframe as the COVID-19 variant began to be recognized and controlled.  There is an exponential increase in the control of COVID and variants once the problem is well identified and it appears that vaccine production and distribution is occurring at an accelerated rate.

Adjusting up slightly for a post-August 1 prediction, as the preponderance of schools appear to be choosing to return to in person education. This seems likely to increase the number of transmissions and the amount of testing (which would serve to better document any higher caseload).

Stats from the holiday will likely lag, not revealing in full force until at least January.  Employers will likely include mitigation factors that may screw initial COVID numbers for the workforce returning from the holiday.  Hence, foundational numbers used by decision-makers will be most reliable in early February.  If testing and other mitigation decisions/strategies are made and implemented, their effect will not be detected until at least March and cases will slowly decrease over time.

The omicron wave is a little bit steeper and sharper (but shorter) the the other waves if we see the way it paned out in the South Africa. Going by their rate of progression there should be a reprieve after 1.5-3 months from the beginning of the wave - that should be somewhere late-February. But to account for the size differences and the way US is spread out as a country, we should also assume a longer wave-down point, so a month (at least) was added to the prediction making it somewhere around late March, early April.

Based on rough eyeballing of Google's COVID tracker in South Africa and UK, they both peaked about 3-4 weeks after when cases really started accelerating upwards, and dropped almost as rapidly afterwards. Cases in other countries like Canada and Australia appear to be peaking close to 3-4 weeks after initial takeoff as well, though it's too early to say for sure. Given this, as a base case, we would expect the US to begin peaking in the next week, then returning to "baseline" after perhaps another 8 weeks (rough eyeball of South Africa's chart). Then perhaps another few weeks to drop below 50k. However, it does throw a wrench into the estimation that the baseline pre-omicron wasn't below 50k. I assume this reflects a persistent relaxing of restrictions and a return to some kind of normal, compared to periods of time following previous waves when <50k was achieved. Given the politics involved, I wouldn't expect restrictions to return, meaning that instead of 8-10 weeks after the peak, we might be looking at a much longer time horizon.

Might see a decrease in March/April. However, with the insane numbers, it may not get below 50,000 / day. Like some others are saying, Omnicron moves fast. But even if it moves quickly through the population, it will be just as fast to mutate to stay infectious and (re)infect those that are vulnerable. Then as the weather gets nicer, it will go up again as people start summer get-togethers and activities. The US has hardly seen less than 50,000 / day except at the beginning of the pandemic and for a couple of short periods in the last few years (with less infectious strains).  Combine that with lockdown fatigue evident in many countries and this is setting up to likely run a rampant course well into 2022.
Rule #1: Things happen much, much faster with Omicron than you’d expect from analogy with other variants’ evolution in 2020 / 2021.

In 2021, we almost dipped below this level on 22 Mar before climbing again. We got there 1 May and stayed below that threshold until 23 Jul, never (yet) to return. We haven't seen Omicron run its course in a single country yet (maybe South Africa, maybe), but it seems to have peaked in a number of population centers, including London, Copenhagen, maybe Manhattan. Uncertainties: can omicron infect the same people multiple times? Will another even more contagious variant resistant to our existing antibodies emerge? I'm, for the moment, bullish on omicron infecting basically everyone and then receding just as quickly.

UPDATE: The math for this projection is sobering, especially if a few assumptions hold true. The first assumption is the slope of the decline from a peak 7-day average will be reasonably consistent with the previous two surges and drops (~-100000 cases/month consistent recovery, -200000 cases/month for quick recovery). Secondly, since the current 7-day average is still climbing, one could assume that the surge will maximize in January and begin to decline like last year closer to February. More troubling is the climb down from this surge is well above previous waves (I assumed ~900000 peak). Using simple linear math (equation of a line y=mx+b), a 7-day moving average of 50k is 4-9 months away. Using an exponential model (y=ab^x) to reflect the realities of both growth and decay wrt a static population and previous declines from surges, we are looking at a range of 3-5 months.  Several variables can cause this projection to fall apart. Poor testing metrics (previous and current) skewed by test availability would likely make this projection less useful. Additionally, the introduction of additional variants and remaining unknowns about the recent omicron variant could add even more entropy and drive a recalibration of the projection.

Previous COVID strains have been on a two-month cycle, couple that with the winter months, and that I don't think we have seen the post-holiday surge...I believe peak omicron won't happen until late January/ early February.  It will still take a month or so after peak for the numbers to get below 50k.
reducing from Bin 5, upping to Bin 4
The high speed of transmission implies a faster rate of decline. Shifting toward sooner rather than later. .

Slightly shifted probabilities after recent numbers.  There is actually a lower chance of reaching August 1st, not because we recover, but because we run out of infectible population.  That is, we reach herd immunity so quickly.

As high as cases are right now, I still think there is a real chance the answer can end up in Bin 2. South Africa's cases skyrocketed for a month, and then they have been plummeting ever since. They started going up in mid/late November for SA, and I suspect that they will be close to pre-omicron levels there by late January. America is about a month behind, so it's not unreasonable to think that we'll be back to pre-omicron levels in late Feb / early March. It is summer in SA and winter in USA, so that can certainly work against America in how soon the surge lets up, and even USA's pre-omicron levels are above 50,000. That said, delta is less a part of the picture now, and even if it doesn't get completely crowded out by omicron, immunity from an omicron infection seems to protect against previous strains (such as delta) quite strongly.

Statistics for South Africa indicate a steep peak and precipitous decline in new cases.  IHME forcastes a steep decline reaching near 50k in April/May.  There are likely new variants coming which could push daily covid cases past August.

In March-June 2021 likely due to the vaccination availability the US saw under 50,000 cases. That was the first time since August 2020. COVID appears to have seasonal surges, around holidays and in the winter because of indoor activities and large gatherings. I would expect, given the amount of vaccinated people and the appearance of warmer weather, to see a shift in lower numbers.

baseline assumptions - last peak was Jan 11 (approx 250k) and next occurance below 50k was May 1, 21 - assuming standard decrease - 1822 decease a day; prior peak (July 4 2020) and Aug 18 below 50k (although significantly lower initial case count in July) - had an avg decrease of 2150 a day - applying average 1986 a day decrease in cases. Prediction based on peak being achieved in 2 weeks and then an average decrease - results in last June below 50k - most likely at earliest - any weeks prior to peak will likely push to the right

The math for this projection is sobering, especially if a few assumptions hold true. The first assumption is the slope of the decline from a peak 7-day average will be reasonably consistent with the previous two surges and drops (~-48000 cases/month consistent recovery, -96000 cases/month for quick recovery). Secondly, since the current 7-day average is still climbing, one could assume that the surge will maximize in January and begin to decline like last year closer to February. More troubling is the climb down from this surge is well above previous waves (I assumed ~900000 peak). Using simple linear math (equation of a line), a 7-day moving average of 50k is 10-17 months away.  Several variables can cause this projection to fall apart. Poor testing metrics (previous and current) skewed by test availability would likely make this projection less useful. Additionally, the introduction of additional variants and remaining unknowns about the recent omicron variant could add even more entropy and drive a recalibration of the projection.

From the last spike of COVID-19 cases (in January 2021) to a return to under 50,000 cases took approximately 5 months. That spike only reached around 250,000, whereas the current spike is around 830,000 and still trending up. Given the much higher numbers, a decline to below 50,000 is likely to take even longer in this instance. Three unknowns mitigating this prediction are the staying power of the new omicron variant (i.e., perhaps it will burn through the population much more quickly) and the testing rate (which might be declining due to a combination of lack of interest and lack of test availability, leading to a lower rate of case reporting). An unknown that could strengthen the prediction is the likelihood of greater covid numbers leading to the creation of a new, even more transmissible variant.

This spike is extremely sharp and cannot be sustained for long. I am tempted to make Feb-March the highest probability bucket but I wonder if the spike will be pronounced but then we will see a slower decrease once we get back to pre-Omicron numbers
Rapid decrease of Omicron as per South Africa is key, however cases running at 1mill/day will take some time to come down to 50K

Base rate: Using the January 2021 surge; similar to current surge in 1) vaccines available - although not as prevalent as they are today, and 2) winter season marked by more indoor contact by individuals practicing relaxed social distancing following the rollout of vaccinations (similar to our current state of being).  New cases peaked on January 8th 2021 at 294,000 cases (6.7% infection rate). On January 11, 2021 the 7-day moving average peaked at 250,541 daily cases (a 3 day lag between the peak cases and peak 7-day average). It was May 1, 2021 before the 7-day moving average dropped below 50K daily cases. I don't do math, so I am going to say generally that 7-day moving average cases decreased by 80% over 110 days.  This article from January 6, 2022 suggests that the US Omicron variant peak could be in the next few weeks, followed by a rapid decline in cases as evidenced by current observations in South Africa and the UK. This sentiment is being reported widely, so I take it at face value that the statement is *generally* accurate given the really smart doctors and scientists weighing in. For planning purposes I will assume the US will peak in new daily COVID cases on or about January 20, 2022, based on the swift reaction across parts of the US to contain the infection rate. https://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2022/01/omicron-could-peak-in-u-s-fairly-soon-maybe/  I am also assuming that the decline in cases will follow the trend of the previous January 2021 surge in terms of rate. I attribute rate (increase or decline) as a factor of the size, demographics, density, and ideological / political leanings of our country, which have not changed much since last January. Specifically, I dont think there will be a sharper decline in the 7-day average.  As of January 7, 2022 new cases were reported at 831,304 with a 7-day moving average of 668,497 (18.16% infection rate).  CDC data suggests that the 7-day moving average recorded on January 5, 2022 had increased 85.7% from the previous week. Assuming that rate of infection remains stable through January 20, 2022, I can estimate the 7-day moving average to be in the neighborhood of 1.088M on January 12, 2022, and 2.021M on January 19, 2022.  So - how many days to go from 2.021M average new cases on the 7-day average, down to 49.9K? Using my terribly rudimentary rate, I project the 7-day moving average to be: 2,021,000 on Jan 20, 2022
404,200 on May 9, 2022
80,840 on August 26, 2022 My lack of confidence in my math skill is what leads me to project a 58% chance we will drop below 50K by 31 July. Its ironic, I know.

Recent variant spike combined with slow/inaccurate data reporting does not build enough confidence COVID numbers will reduce significantly; moreover, political polarization on the issue has kept vaccination counts lower than ought to be.
Reasonable timeframe for the vaccine to be tailored to the omicron variant and for cases to stabilize.

Expecting COVID numbers to drop once we hit spring and the weather is warmer. Also, more folks and kids will have their booster/shots

Based on the peaks of the Omicron variant in South Africa and UK, and estimates the US will peak in mid January, I estimate the most likely scenario is that the US moving average will be below 50K in the second quarter of 2022.
New test that can differentiate between covid and the flu, and the omicron variant will have run its course.

Based on the speed of the omicron variant and how quickly South Africa saw the peak subside.
Additionally, the lower severity and reduced quarantine period serves to limit the interest in testing resulting in fewer overall detections of COVID.
Initial guess, skewing sooner vis-a-vis the crowd based on Omicron's rapid rise, and (possible) rapid fall.

bin 1: no chance, as Omicron cases are still rising.
bin 2: big chance, as even with the ancestral strain last year, cases would have fallen below 50k/day by March 31, 2021 if not for Alpha, and Omicron cases can be expected to fall much more quickly than ancestral variant cases did last year. If we could know that no other variant would emerge, I'd be almost certain that bin 2 would be the outcome.
bin 3: possible, as a new variant could arise. Last year, Alpha came up, but cases still fell <50k/day by May 1.
bin 4: possible if a wild new variant emerges that causes a large spike in cases, larger than the relatively small Alpha wave last year, or if 2 smaller waves succeed Omicron.
bin 5: it's hard to see how bin 5 could happen, based on last year's experience. Some combination of 2-4 new variants would need to emerge that would need to be timed well enough to cause sequential waves large enough to prevent cases from dipping <50k/day in between. I don't rule out bin 5, but it seems really unlikely that the pandemic situation would be worse in year 3 in this way than in year 2.

From the last peak to below 50,000 was about 4.5 months. Whilst the peak is much higher this time there should be a greater level of immunity from vaccine and past infection which should quicken the path out. There will also likely be reduced number of people getting tested either through changes to requirements and/or community frustration.

From a much lower peak with less contagious variants, from peak to trough was nearly 7 months. It is probable that the peak is still 1-3 weeks away. Re-infection with omicron may be higher than past variants, so past infection may mean less than last year. Anecdotally, I was in a big box store today. In contrast to weeks past, almost every customer was wearing a mask. If this was a sample of widespread behavior, rates could fall sharply. The other way that rates could drop more sharply would be if testing was significantly decreased - for example only in hospitalized patients. Shifting testing cost to patients or creating co-pays might really shut down testing, and detection independent of prevelance.

The first surge took ~6 months from start to finish; delta's peak took ~4 months.  As things get more infectious it is harder to flatten the curve.  Plus we are employing less social distancing measures to do so.  Omicron should burn out faster than delta.  My guess is 2.5 months.  Cases started jumping around dec17th, so my guess is that the peak will be 1st or 2nd week in february and we will be at a nadir around march 1st.  
One question is whether another variant will come around that can outcompete omicron.  Delta rose to prominence because it was more infectious that the original strain. 
 That's getting harder and harder to do as variants get more and more infectious.  Omicron rose to prominence partially because of a higher infectious rate and also because it evades immunity.  That seems the more likely route for new variants to come up.  How likely is that to happen?  Not sure, but if it happens, it's likely to happen faster than it did for delta, since omicron will flare and die down faster than delta did.  
Let's say there is a new variant.  It will likely be as infectious as omicron, but not more - the reason it will rise is because it can infect people who already have immunity.  That means that the time from start to finish of a new wave would be the same - 2.5 months.  That would put us at June-July timeline.     Lastly, there's a pretty high chance that this will be endemic and that our cases will never fall below 50,000.  I'm not sure how to figure out the likelihood of that, but i put it at 30%

Considering the 2021's 1st semester  pattern, the total number of cases will be below the 50.000 cases/day between 1st April and 31st May. However, as the Omicron variant has a faster rate of replication, faster resolution may follow an hyperacute peak.

We don’t have any lockdown measures in place like we did last year (when it took until May 2021 for cases to reach 50,000 after the winter surge), but we also now have about 60% of our population vaccinated…and likely more with natural immunity after this surge.  Given these two variables, Omicron and our winter season are complete wild cards (being a La Niña year), so it’s hard to say how COVID will spread this winter. If it stays cold through February and into March, COVID most likely will continue to wreak havoc until the humidity/heat rises. Additionally, if it stays cold and/or another variant emerges due to the rapid Omicron spread, this question wont resolve until summer.  Omicron seems to peak quickly, but it’s hard to predict our particular path right now against data from other countries, since we don’t have comparable healthcare/public health systems or the same mandates in place. I’m not sure on how we will react to this new surge, but as we return from the holidays and businesses/government make new decisions, I may be able to update percentages more effectively.  https://www.cnn.com/2021/10/14/weather/la-nina-develops-2021/index.html
Late spring/early summer at the latest, possibly earlier since most people will get immunity pretty fast

Initial guess. Omicron should come down as fast as it went up, if South Africa’s experience is anything to go by.
Also, if infection by Omicron blocks Delta, then cases from Delta should also decline significantly very soon.
